subject: Art
title: How Cameras Work
description: Light enters a box through a hole and records an image ‚Äî it's been that simple for 200 years.

hook.text: A camera is a light-tight box with a hole. Light enters through the hole, passes through a lens, and hits a sensor (or film). That's it. Every camera from a pinhole to a $50,000 cinema rig works on this same principle.

buildup.text: Three components: the lens (focuses light), the shutter (controls how long light hits the sensor), and the sensor/film (records the light pattern). Together they capture a moment of light and freeze it.

discovery.text: The sensor converts light photons into electrical signals, which become pixels. More photons = brighter pixel. Different wavelengths = different colors. Millions of tiny light measurements, assembled into an image.

twist.text: Your phone camera works identically to a DSLR ‚Äî same physics, same principles. The difference is sensor size, lens quality, and controls. Understanding how cameras work makes you better with ANY camera, including your phone.

climax.text: Try this: make a pinhole camera from a box and aluminum foil. Poke a tiny hole, point it at a bright scene, and look at the back wall ‚Äî you'll see an inverted image. That's photography reduced to its essence.

punchline.text: Light + box + hole = photograph. Everything else is refinement.
